document.masterDocTitle: Stenopodidean shrimps (Crustacea: Decapoda) from New Caledonian waters

Measurements (mm). Females, PCL: 2.3 –6.0; RCL: 3.0– 7.3 ; TL: 8.9–18.8 . Males, PCL: 2.5–4.9 ; RCL: 2.7 – 6.0; TL: 9.0– 16.3 . Eggs are few in number ( 7–169 ) early developmental eggs measured on average 0.75 × 0.80 mm ; eggs in late stage of development were 0.81 × 0.95 mm on average.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6 .
Spongicola goyi Saito & Komai, 2008
. A–D. female, MNHM Na-11986; E–J. male, MNHN Na-11986. A, carapace, dorsal view; B, carapace and abdomen, lateral view; C, carapace, anterolateral view; D, telson and uropods; E, first pereiopod; F. detail of setiferous organ, first pereiopod; G, second pereiopod; H, right third pereiopod; I, fourth pereiopod; J, propodus and dactylus, fourth pereiopod. Scale bars = 1.0 mm.

FIGURE 7 .
Spongicola levigatus Hayashi & Ogawa, 1987
. A, B, D, female, MNHN Na-11987; C, E, male, MNHN Na-11987. A, female; B, carapace, dorsal view; C, carapace and abdomen, lateral view; D, telson and uropods; E, left third pereiopod. Scale bar = 1.0 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution . Japan , Indonesia , Tonga , New Caledonia , Loyalty Islands, Australia , and Wallis and Futuna Islands (see Remarks).

Hosts .
Saito & Komai ( 2008 )
reported this species in the sponges
Hyalonema
sp.,
Semperella
sp.,
Pheronema semiglobosum
and
Euplectella
sp.

Remarks . This species was thoroughly described by
Saito & Komai ( 2008 )
and is not redescribed here. The mouthparts and variation of spination on the carapace are illustrated here (
Figs. 7
A–E, 8 F–I). This species was the most numerous encountered during this study and was frequently found associated with the hexactinellid sponge,
Pheronema semiglobosum
. An additional
10 specimens
of this species were examined from the northwest shelf of Australia ( NTM Cr 0 0 11112 , Cr003652, Cr008128, and Cr008129).
De Grave ( 2004 )
reported two specimens of
Spongicola levigatus
from New Caledonia collected with the paratype of the alpheid
Batella praecipina
and the pontoniid
Perclimenes forcipulatus .
